snippet.textDisplay:
Seriously. Why are we making videos like this? This topic was a nightmare. How do you talk about a continent as diverse as Africa, to explain larger trends? Not only is there a wide variety of sources, experts disagree with each other on what they can predict about the future. So the time we took to rewrite this script over and over was insane.


Still, there is no chance this video won’t make people angry, on all sides of this issue. Some may not agree with the conclusions we have come to. Some will think there are other aspects we could and should have mentioned. Or lament that we generalized too much.


But we had to generalize or this video would just have become a hour-long documentary. And we think the topic is too important to not discuss it.


So we read a lot and talked too many experts with very different opinions and interpretations. Also we tried to prepare our sources in a way that walks you through our thought process and helps you to make up your own mind.


This video was sponsored by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation as part of a Grant. They did not take part in the production of the video though.


Sources and comments: https://sites.google.com/view/sourcesoverpopulationandafrica

Still, there is no chance this video won’t make people angry, on all sides of this issue. Some may not agree with the conclusions we have come to. Some will think there are other aspects we could and should have mentioned. Or lament that we generalized too much. 


But we had to generalize or this video would just have become a hour-long documentary. And we think the topic is too important to not discuss it.


So we read a lot and talked too many experts with very different opinions and interpretations. Also we tried to prepare our sources in a way that walks you through our thought process and helps you to make up your own mind.

Sources and comments: https://sites.google.com/view/sourcesoverpopulationandafrica

snippet.textDisplay: I like this channel and this video very much, however; the premise presumes that population growth necessarily precludes economic success. It is much more interesting to me to imagine a continent full of young educated people as the largest demographic. With modern technology it is totally feasible to educate the masses relatively inexpensively. I can imagine that feeding a large population would be tough, but not impossible. I have heard from some very smart sources, including African expats, that Africa doesn't have a food production issue it has a food distribution issue. In the video it frames the education of women as a means to an end instead of an end in itself.  Educate women because it is good in the now. Their children in turn, will be educated by them, and be good in the future. Even if the population growth rate doesn't decline in the predicted way, then very well because now there's a larger population of educated peoples. The utilitarian-esque view point that you have to maximize quality of life while also necessarily minimizing quantity of lives is silent on the very real possibility that you can maximize both to a point. Of course earth's resources are finite but it seems to me a little backwards to employ population control before attempting to optimize resource usages, including human resources. Basically, I'm advocating for taking into account maximum population growth and planning to optimizing all those new people (aka new producers and consumers). Because no matter what, if we have the max number of people or the minimum, they will be of maximum quality.

With modern technology it is totally feasible to educate the masses relatively inexpensively. I can imagine that feeding a large population would be tough, but not impossible. I have heard from some very smart sources, including African expats, that Africa doesn't have a food production issue it has a food distribution issue. In the video it frames the education of women as a means to an end instead of an end in itself.  Educate women because it is good in the now. Their children in turn, will be educated by them, and be good in the future. Even if the population growth rate doesn't decline in the predicted way, then very well because now there's a larger population of educated peoples. The utilitarian-esque view point that you have to maximize quality of life while also necessarily minimizing quantity of lives is silent on the very real possibility that you can maximize both to a point. Of course earth's resources are finite but it seems to me a little backwards to employ population control before attempting to optimize resource usages, including human resources. Basically, I'm advocating for taking into account maximum population growth and planning to optimizing all those new people (aka new producers and consumers). Because no matter what, if we have the max number of people or the minimum, they will be of maximum quality.

snippet.textDisplay: May be naiive here, but my opinion is that there is SO SO SO much land without people on it. So... over population should never be a concern in the foreseeable future. Would be interesting to find some stats for how much land is unihabited by people and/or populated by a small enough density to meet some determined cut-off point that makes sense. "Over population", I think, should actually be called "people choosing to pack into a small space instead of spreading out" - which... puts it on the person to be responsible for their actions and life (which is my worldview. NOT a fan of those looking to point fingers about why their life is sub-par). Anyway, some thoughts..

snippet.textDisplay:
Asian turnaround? You can thank China centrally planned economy (at least was until market reforms in the 1970s turned it further towards free market capitalism). This completely ignores the laws of capitalism which has booms and busts, or 'slumps' as it is sometimes called. The mode in which production or consumption is conducted may change but the fundamental laws governing capital have not changed since the industrial revolution. you also ignore unfair trade deals the EU and the US (as well as China) force many African nations into creating a net loss in profits for them as they export raw resources to fuel global markets.

To me this video is trying to stretch the term 'trickle down economics' over the whole planet and its arguments on that scale are so far stretched you can practically see right through it.

The next decade will be faced with a simple question: Socialism or Barbarism!

To me this video is trying to stretch the term 'trickle down economics' over the whole planet and its arguments on that scale are so far stretched you can practically see right through it.
 
The next decade will be faced with a simple question: Socialism or Barbarism!

snippet.textDisplay: the increase in "Family Planning" has had disastrous effects on the western worlds fertility rate. In it's most extreme cases you wind up with China, where there is now 30 million more boys than girls.   The term is used as "framing" for any policy that dissuades people from having large families. No people should be trying to control the populations of others, We often don't understand the consequences that interfering with reproduction will have on the next generation. Nature should just be allowed to take its course.

snippet.textDisplay:
It won't be popular but, there is one more important factor. Average IQ level on sub saharan Africa is under 85. In Europe is around 100 IQ. FarEast around 110 IQ and Australian Aboriginal is just 62 IQ.
There is a corelation between climate and IQ. In cold climate and four seasons, the whole population could die in just one year. The most inteligent people were able to kill a bear, make a clothes from his fur, build house which keep warm, store food through the winter ect. So nature selected the most inteligent people, who gave their genes to next generations.
That is why Subsaharian Africans and Australian Aboriginal didn't develop so quiclky. Because there was no rough natural selection of IQ. In Africa or Australia wild animal could kill one unit, but on the north hemisphere, climate could kill entire population.
So, poverty often is the result of a "mental poverty". That's why all African countries should invest all their resources to completelly eliminate the illiteracy at the first place.

The most inteligent people were able to kill a bear, make a clothes from his fur, build house which keep warm, store food through the winter ect. So nature selected the most inteligent people, who gave their genes to next generations. 
That is why Subsaharian Africans and Australian Aboriginal didn't develop so quiclky. Because there was no rough natural selection of IQ. In Africa or Australia wild animal could kill one unit, but on the north hemisphere, climate could kill entire population.

snippet.textDisplay:
Very good video. Appreciate the work you put on it.

Tyre continents of the would have showed time and again the same growth pattern. An initial population held back by limited economy focuses on a high birth rate for survival and growth. Eventually the economy stabilizes improving health and the living standards of the population. The ability to move from basic survival to triving lets the population turn to higher order needs like comfort and happiness which leads to reforms of older systems that were tolerated due to the need to survive. This eventually includes women who typically start out as..to be blunt..baby factories in the early days.

Better health leads to a baby boom as the large birth rate isn't countered by a large death rate. and more freedoms leads to the population choosing (or sadly being forced to) have less children. The birth rate then drops. We're yet to see a country avoid this or reverse it even when the country tries to do so.

Colonization tended to add in infrastructure at the cost of freedom and economy. Thus countries that got the infrastructure and got out of colonization got to move on into jumpstarting their population trend. Continents like Africa and the Middle East though were pretty darn ravaged by mettling from other countries especially when that country ops to encourage oppressive situations without even adding in investment in the population. A lot of the remaining "third world" are being exploited for some kind of resource via war or black market that doesn't the country the way that the sweatshops of China at least offered (sadly Sweatshops are the'better' types of exploitation. Less "it's a good thing" and more"there's much much worse").

Africa is diverse and mixed in its issues but I the end it's just waiting forthe same chance that every other continent received. Once it does it'll go the way of any other nation.

As far as when that happens, from what I hear it already has started. Some of the countries are already developed enough to start on the population path. As for others, I've heard that China is pushing hard for investment I the infrastructure, possibly to do for it what the US did for China (if true expect reports of major job p
Opportunities followed by reports of exploited workers, a massive rise in pollution, culture clashes, possiblyan exploding population, ...ext ext go read the growth of China and India, Japan post ww2, the US post Ww2 and so on. )

After that..we will see.

 Better health leads to a baby boom as the large birth rate isn't countered by a large death rate. and more freedoms leads to the population choosing (or sadly being forced to) have less children.  The birth rate then drops. We're yet to see a country avoid this or reverse it even when the country tries to do so.

snippet.textDisplay:
This video, like all of Kurzgesagt's content, is clearly well researched and well made. But there is a dark undertone to this one which I'm surprised to find. Throughout the video, we are implicitly taken to understand that a lower population in Africa is a good thing, and that either of the projected population numbers given at the beginning are 'overpopulation'. This isn't explained or justified. Instead, the idea of African births, African children, African lives, are just linked directly to problems.
If the projected population numbers are expected to lead to a lower quality of life, then that needs to be stated and explained. If there are good reasons to think that sub-Saharan Africans would benefit from lower birth rates, give them. Without those reasons and justifications, we are left with an argument which just seems... a bit racist.
snippet.textOriginal:
This video, like all of Kurzgesagt's content, is clearly well researched and well made. But there is a dark undertone to this one which I'm surprised to find. Throughout the video, we are implicitly taken to understand that a lower population in Africa is a good thing, and that either of the projected population numbers given at the beginning are 'overpopulation'. This isn't explained or justified. Instead, the idea of African births, African children, African lives, are just linked directly to problems. 
If the projected population numbers are expected to lead to a lower quality of life, then that needs to be stated and explained. If there are good reasons to think that sub-Saharan Africans would benefit from lower birth rates, give them. Without those reasons and justifications, we are left with an argument which just seems... a bit racist.

snippet.authorDisplayName: Oh my god, my heart is- my heart is oh my god!
snippet.textDisplay:
I went on a trip to South Africa and Namibia in early 2018. Many things were similar to my home - the African people acted much like Canadian people, the cities looked very similar, many of their customs were similar. But one thing that was really shocking to me was the sexual culture.

Children became sexually active at strikingly young ages in Namibia. Some of the girls I talked to were only 10. It wasn't abnormal for 13-year-old girls to fall pregnant. When I spoke to these girls, it seemed as though sex was an expectation: "I want to make my boyfriend happy, so we have sex." It was as if they feared their partners would leave them if they didn't become sexual. At the same time, awareness of contraception was not very high at all - a huge portion of the population had contracted and was dying from AIDS.

Many of these girls would have a child by 18 - for some, even more than one. The school drop-out rates were sky-high, especially for young girls. Graduating from elementary school was seen as a huge accomplishment for all genders. Rarely did any of the girls ever aspire towards a university education, and typically their life plan was to graduate from elementary, maybe attend high school, and then raise their children.

So, yes, overpopulation is a big problem in sub-Saharan Africa because it limits economical advancement and requires thin distribution of resources. But, we also need to recognize how overpopulation affects the youth - both boys and girls. Sure, overpopulation should be tackled for the sake of the countries' economies, but it should especially be tackled so these young girls can have dreams outside of motherhood, so these young boys are raised in a culture that respects men and women equally.
snippet.textOriginal:
I went on a trip to South Africa and Namibia in early 2018. Many things were similar to my home - the African people acted much like Canadian people, the cities looked very similar, many of their customs were similar. But one thing that was really shocking to me was the sexual culture.

Children became sexually active at strikingly young ages in Namibia. Some of the girls I talked to were only 10. It wasn't abnormal for 13-year-old girls to fall pregnant. When I spoke to these girls, it seemed as though sex was an expectation: "I want to make my boyfriend happy, so we have sex." It was as if they feared their partners would leave them if they didn't become sexual. At the same time, awareness of contraception was not very high at all - a huge portion of the population had contracted and was dying from AIDS.

Many of these girls would have a child by 18 - for some, even more than one. The school drop-out rates were sky-high, especially for young girls. Graduating from elementary school was seen as a huge accomplishment for all genders. Rarely did any of the girls ever aspire towards a university education, and typically their life plan was to graduate from elementary, maybe attend high school, and then raise their children.

So, yes, overpopulation is a big problem in sub-Saharan Africa because it limits economical advancement and requires thin distribution of resources. But, we also need to recognize how overpopulation affects the youth - both boys and girls. Sure, overpopulation should be tackled for the sake of the countries' economies, but it should especially be tackled so these young girls can have dreams outside of motherhood, so these young boys are raised in a culture that respects men and women equally.

South Korea: We’ve made it VERY WELL. TOO WELL. But our gov. noticed this fact too late, so we couldn’t stop birth control in a right time.

Now our birth rate is about 0.8 and it’s still dropping fast. So, our population will decrease in a close future. Now my generation is expected to have little public care system or pensions, since no young people will be there to pay taxes for us.

snippet.textDisplay: I am from Bangladesh and the context makes sense...as a country of majority Muslim and Hindu population, I used to hear that men used to have 1-2 wives at least...some even had 3 but that was long, long ago. Now the rate capped down to 1. And Education is plenty though in the rural places people live under unfortunate circumstances and consider education as a luxury so they don't spend money on it for girls. And although it is illegal I saw through my own eyes girls getting married under 15 so they have an even lower chance to get proper education. But other than that, thankfully, we took huge treads in decreasing population from 7 kids to 2. So proud of my country for that. And what's an even bigger coincidence my country's Independence day is today so patriotism is even soaring high. Hope things take a turn for much much better if God wills.

snippet.textDisplay: I think the real problem is with countries being unstable, it leads to many problems with development for example companies from developed countries don't want to invest, internal conflicts can destroy 1/3 of what was build and the high distances between each city makes communication difficult. Also I'd say the Asian countries that implemented free market or large reforms to making it freier got them developed very fast. The other difference is the culture it is pretty obvious that there are cultures that have hard work build in them. We know that the people from these cultures are really good for economy and development of country. For example there are cultures where not working is regarded as huge failure in life and in others there is no problem with not working. Also there are countries with no national identity and it is very bad for country especially when it's poor or underdeveloped.
